column4: A tropical-herbal shooter mixing Jägermeister, coconut rum, and pineapple.
column5: The Surfer on Acid subverts the aggressive reputation of Jägermeister by pairing it with sweet coconut rum and pineapple juice. The result is a murky, tropical shot where the herbal bitterness of the Jäger adds a tiki-like spice to the fruit. It is surprisingly complex and drinkable, tasting of pineapples, anise, and coconut. It was a staple of the West Coast surf/skate punk scene in the 1990s.
column6: Shake a Surfer on Acid with Jägermeister and coconut rum.
column12: A Surfer on Acid shot in a glass with a dark
column24: Can also be served as a long drink over ice, but the shot format is the cultural standard.
column25: Created by bartender Eric Tecosky in Los Angeles in the 1990s, who famously championed Jägermeister as a mixable spirit rather than just a frozen shot.
column28: 1 oz Jägermeister|1 oz coconut rum|1 oz pineapple juice
column29: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a shot glass.

column4: A creamy, layered Alaskan classic of whiskey, Irish cream, and coffee liqueur.
column5: The Duck Fart is Alaska's unofficial state drink, a layered shooter that stacks whiskey (specifically Crown Royal) over Irish cream and Kahlúa. It is a B-52 variant that swaps the orange liqueur for whiskey, creating a warmer, maltier profile. The layers are meant to be drunk in one go, delivering a progression of strong spirit followed by sweet, creamy dessert flavors.
column6: Layer a Duck Fart shot with Kahlúa, Bailey's, and whiskey.
column12: A layered Duck Fart shot showing distinct brown
column25: Pour slowly over the back of a spoon to keep the layers distinct; density is key.
column26: Created at the Peanut Farm bar in Anchorage, Alaska, in the 1980s, allegedly named for the sound made by a patron after consuming a few.
column29: 0.5 oz coffee liqueur (bottom)|0.5 oz Irish cream (middle)|0.5 oz Canadian whisky (top)
column30: 1. Pour coffee liqueur into a shot glass. 2. Layer Irish cream gently on top using a spoon. 3. Layer whisky on the very top. 4. Shoot immediately.

column4: A dessert shooter tasting exactly like the pastry.
column5: The Pineapple Upside Down Cake is a flavored vodka shooter that uncannily recreates the flavor of the classic cake. It mixes vanilla vodka with pineapple juice, finished with a sink of grenadine that mimics the cherry base of the dessert. It is sweet, fruity, and nostalgic, relying on the vanilla-pineapple pairing to sell the 'cake' illusion. It is a staple of 2000s bachelorette parties and birthday rounds.
column6: Shake a Pineapple Upside Down Cake shot with vanilla vodka and grenadine.
column12: A yellow pineapple shot with a red grenadine layer at the bottom.
column23: Let the grenadine settle at the bottom for the correct visual effect before serving.
column24: This drink exemplifies the 'pastry profile' trend of the 2000s, driven by the release of vanilla-flavored vodkas.
column27: 1.5 oz vanilla vodka|1.5 oz pineapple juice|0.25 oz grenadine
column28: 1. Shake vodka and pineapple juice with ice. 2. Strain into a shot glass. 3. Slowly pour grenadine down the side; it will sink to the bottom. 4. Garnish with a maraschino cherry (optional).

column4: A smooth, peach-forward shooter with a whiskey bite.
column5: The Water Moccasin is a popular party shot that blends peach schnapps with Canadian whisky and sweet-and-sour mix. It is effectively a shot version of the Green Tea shot's cousin, offering a fruity, tangy profile with a golden-green hue. The whiskey cuts the syrup of the schnapps, making it dangerously easy to drink. It is a staple of high-volume college bars and clubs.
column6: Shake a Water Moccasin shot with whiskey, peach schnapps, and sour.
column12: A Water Moccasin shot in a glass with a golden-yellow color.
column23: Using fresh lemon and lime (homemade sour) elevates this significantly above the bottled-mix version.
column24: Named after the venomous snake, likely due to its deceptive smoothness—it bites you only after you've had a few.
column27: 1 oz Canadian whisky|1 oz peach schnapps|1 oz sour mix (or lemon/lime/sugar)
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a shot glass.

column4: A fruity, berry-laced whisky shot named for the winning hand.
column5: The Royal Flush is a casino classic that pairs Crown Royal with peach schnapps and cranberry juice. It is essentially a Washington Apple with peach instead of apple, resulting in a rounder, softer fruit profile. It is deep red, sweet-tart, and smooth, designed to be ordered in celebratory rounds at the blackjack table. It balances the oak of the whisky with the stone fruit and berry notes.
column6: Shake a Royal Flush shot with Crown Royal, peach, and cranberry.
column12: A Royal Flush shot in a glass with a deep red hue.
column23: Raspberry liqueur (Chambord) is sometimes substituted for the cranberry juice for a richer, more expensive version.
column24: The drink's name and its primary ingredient (Crown Royal) are a deliberate marketing synergy popular in Las Vegas casinos.
column27: 1 oz Canadian whisky|0.5 oz peach schnapps|0.5 oz cranberry juice
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a shot glass. 4. Shoot.

column4: A ritual shot tasting of pancakes, chased with orange juice.
column5: The Breakfast Shot (or Irish Breakfast Shot) is a two-part drink that famously tastes like a plate of pancakes with syrup. It combines Jameson Irish Whiskey and butterscotch schnapps, followed immediately by a chaser of orange juice. The alchemy of the butterscotch and whiskey followed by the citrus acidity recreates the flavor of maple syrup and bacon on the palate. It is a popular 'hair of the dog' choice for brunch.
column6: Serve a Breakfast Shot: whiskey and butterscotch with an OJ chaser.
column12: A Breakfast Shot setup with an amber shot and a small glass of orange juice.
column23: Some versions include a side of bacon to complete the sensory illusion.
column24: While the exact origin is unknown, it became a brunch staple in the 2010s for its uncanny ability to mimic breakfast flavors.
column27: 0.75 oz Irish whiskey|0.75 oz butterscotch schnapps|1.5 oz orange juice (served separately)
column28: 1. Shake whiskey and butterscotch schnapps with ice and strain into a shot glass. 2. Pour orange juice into a separate glass. 3. Drink the shot, then immediately drink the juice.

column4: A utilitarian, low-calorie highball combining vodka and diet cola.
column5: The Yoozh (for The Usual) or commonly referred to as a VDC (Vodka Diet Coke) is a functional highball defined by its caloric efficiency and caffeine content. Unlike the Cuba Libre, which balances rum with sugar and lime, this drink relies entirely on the artificial sweeteners of the diet cola to mask the ethanol of the vodka. It is a staple of modern nightlife and diet-conscious drinking, prized for its simplicity rather than culinary complexity. The lack of sugar allows the vodka's texture to remain prominent, often requiring a lime wedge to provide necessary acidity.
column6: Build The VDC with vodka and Diet Coke for a simple low-calorie highball.
column12: A VDC highball in a tall glass with bubbles and a lime wedge.
column23: Squeeze the lime wedge into the drink before dropping it in; the citric acid is crucial to cutting the aftertaste of artificial sweeteners.
column24: The VDC is the favorite drink of the founder of MixWise!
column27: 2 oz vodka|4 oz Diet Coke (or diet cola)
column28: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice. 2. Add vodka. (Measure with your heart) 3. Top with Diet Coke. 4. Stir briefly to combine. 5. Optionally garnish with a lime wedge.

column4: A visual novelty shot resembling a tiny pint of lager.
column5: The Mini Beer is a clever visual trick shot that perfectly mimics the appearance of a glass of beer on a miniature scale. It uses Licor 43—a bright yellow Spanish vanilla liqueur—to represent the golden lager, topped with a float of heavy cream to simulate the foamy head. Despite the name, it contains no beer ingredients. It is a sweet, creamy shooter defined entirely by its whimsical presentation.
column6: Make a Mini Beer shot with Licor 43 and heavy cream.
column12: A Mini Beer shot looking exactly like a tiny glass of beer with foam.
column23: Chill the Licor 43 beforehand; the temperature difference helps the cream float more easily on top.
column24: Licor 43 is a Spanish liqueur allegedly dating back to 209 BC, though its use in this modern novelty shot is a much more recent phenomenon.
column28: 1. Chill the Licor 43 in the freezer or fridge. 2. Pour the Licor 43 into a shot glass (or miniature beer mug), filling it 3/4 full. 3. Gently float the heavy cream on top using the back of a spoon to create the 'head'. 4. Serve immediately.
